qas.question: Why are capacitors connected in parallel with the power circuits of many devices and large systems?

answers.text: to provide a "clean" power supply for signal or control circuits

qas.question: How do the capacitors connected in parallel act with currents from the power supply?

answers.text: as a local reserve for the DC power source

qas.question: What is one value a stiffening capacitor accounts for when used in for car audio purposes?
What is another value a stiffening capacitor accounts for when used in for car audio purposes?
What do parallel capacitors do to fluctuating current in order to deliver "clean" power for control circuits?

plausible_answers.text: to provide a "clean" power supply for signal or control circuits

qas.question: Why are capacitors connected in parallel without the power circuits of many devices and large systems?

plausible_answers.text: as a local reserve for the DC power source

qas.question: How do the capacitors connected perpendicullarly act with currents from the power supply?
What is one value a stiffening capacitor accounts for when used in for a plane audio purposes?
What is another value a stiffening capacitor accounts for when used in for boat audio purposes?

plausible_answers.text: conceal current fluctuations from the primary power source

qas.question: What do parallel capacitors do to fluctuating current in order to deliver "dirty" power for control circuits?

context: Capacitors are connected in parallel with the power circuits of most electronic devices and larger systems (such as factories) to shunt away and <a4_0><b9_0>conceal current fluctuations<a4_0/> from the primary power source<b9_0/> <a0_0><b5_0>to provide a "clean" power supply for signal or control circuits<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Audio equipment, for example, uses several capacitors in this way, to shunt away power line hum before it gets into the signal circuitry. The capacitors act <a1_0><b6_0>as a local reserve for the DC power source<b6_0/><a1_0/>, and bypass AC currents from the power supply. This is used in car audio applications, when a stiffening capacitor compensates for <a2_0><b7_0>the inductance<b7_0/><a2_0/> and <a3_0><b8_0>resistance<b8_0/><a3_0/> of the leads to the lead-acid car battery.
